Public Lands and Buildings: Gentlemen — I herewith submit report for the Hiennium ending Noveartwr SO, l'tos. I With this report ■ an estimate of the needs of the Institution the coming biennium. I have asked only for what is really led and trust that same will be approved and appropriation le to provide for the same. II thank you for the support given me. Also I wish to thank officers and members of the Home for the aid given me in the agement of the Home during the time I have l«*en here. Respectfully. I). \Y. Hoyt. Comd'i.

The bookkeeper to lie able to do typewriting. tenance * 120.000. 00 ial repair.- 5,000.00 r system 1.000 00 rage 1.000 00 Painting 1,500 00 Addition to brick hospital kitchen . 3,000.00 ag... ...... 1.500 (HI Administration building 15.000.00 I appropriation for bieonium $190,370 00 1 would recoinniend an appropriation as shown above for an addition to the brick hospital kitchen, as the kitchen at present tirelv to small for the needs of t he hospital, as the new addi- tion now l)eing occupied, makes an increase of about thirty to forty members in that hospital. Also.- an administration building as the rooms now occupied by the offices and officers' families are greatly needed as wards the use of the memlters of the Home. Also. 1 would recommend the appropriation of fifteen hundred ($1500.00) dollars for fencing, as the old fence is dilapidated. and in a very bad condition, and not worth repairing, and is a discredit to the state. There should be an entirely new fence, up to date and in keeping with the times.

'* ( ill. 1). \\ . Hoyt, ( i iinmandant : IDear Sir — Herewith I submit my report for the biennium ing November :«). 1908. Since tlie report of December J. 1906 there have bee deaths, 88 men, and 24 women. 7.5 died at the Hume, and 19 away, while on furlough. We note an increase of ten deaths in this biennium over the preceding one. Still the average af teed is materially higher for this biennium. That of men showing an increase of four years, and that of women seven \ Four of the deaths occurred from unnatural can ■ I The number of hospital patients is rapidly increasing and i day require* additional care and attention. We are pk report that several improvements have been made at the litals. I The stock of drugs and medicine has been increased and basis has been laid upon their quality, that the very tinent might he given to the patients. tThe heating system has been greatly improved, thus giving sufficient heat to maintain a proper temperature which iotislv lacking. The interior of the hospitals have ted and overhauled in general so that conditions are now i' sanitary. The general equipment has received careful ntion. better chairs and l>eds have been supplied, blan ■is and other bed clothing has been furnished, to add to the fort of the patients. The new west wing to the brick hospital has just been cotn - plrted. We have not yet moved into it but it will 1k> ready for occupancy within a few days. In this addition there is room for twenty-seven beds. The building is constructed on modern plans. well painted and has all sanitary equipments, electric lights, steam heat, plenty of light and excellent ventilation. With this additional room there will be sufficient room for the i number of patients for some years at least. II wish to thank the administration for the loyal support I always received, which has greatly aided me in my work Very truly yours. FjDwabd Stacei Dungan, Surgeon.
